elements.content: Practical methods for hydrogen storage are still a major bottleneck in the realization of an energy economy based on hydrogen as an energy carrier. Surface adsorption within crystalline, nanoporous, metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) provides a promising storage method that relies on sufficiently strong adsorption interactions for a large fraction of the storage capacity. Only few MOF structures were studied up to date using neutron diffraction to resolve the adsorption sites. Here we use in situ neutron diffraction to characterize hydrogen (deuterium) adsorption sites in the MOF Cr MIL-53. The strongest adsorption interactions are present at three different sites where the hydrogen touches nearby organic linkers from two directions. Perhaps surprisingly, there is no strong direct interaction with the Cr−O cluster. Large breathing modes of the crystalline lattice are observed upon loading hydrogen reversibly to an equivalent of 5.5 wt %. Such breathing modes are known to occur for polar solvents like H2O, alkanes, and also for the gas CO2; however, as shown here it also occurs for weakly van der Waals adsorbed hydrogen molecules.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hydrogen adsorption in nanoporous materials relies on sufficient strength of the adsorption interaction and the number of adsorption sites. The former determines the operation temperatures and pressures, and the latter determines the storage capacity. In general, a pressure-dependent coverage of surface-adsorption sites occurs which is described by Langmuir isotherms, with increasing coverage at low temperatures and/or higher pressures.

elements.content: Hydrogen adsorption in MOFs has characteristic adsorption enthalpies much lower than the enthalpies of formation of many light metal hydrides. In principle, there is an advantage to this low adsorption interaction because this opens the possibility to have rapid hydrogen adsorption into MOFs for hydrogen storage purposes, without running into the limitations of adsorption heat transport out of the storage material. This heat release is a remaining bottleneck with for instance catalyzed and nanostructured NaAlH4 and MgH2. However, the disadvantage of the currently found adsorption interactions is that they are still that small that significant storage only occurs at temperatures as low as 77 K or exceedingly high pressures. Therefore, the aim is to find optimum adsorption energies where heating effects are still limited but operating temperatures come closer to ambient. Chemical tailoring MOFs to realize such adsorption energies is approached using several routes. In principle, the range of interactions spans from the weak van der Waals adsorption to strong molecular adsorption interactions that are observed in Kubas compounds that contain exposed metal sites of e.g. Cr or W that bind H2 under ambient conditions. Molecular hydrogen can also be bound strongly under ambient conditions to exposed metal sites in zeolites.

elements.content: Neutron diffraction is the only technique that provides direct insight in the position of hydrogen adsorption sites. Only a few MOF structures were studied up to date using neutron diffraction to resolve the possible adsorption sites. Here we investigate the Cr variety of MIL-53 first reported to store significant amounts of hydrogen by the group of Ferey et al. at 77 K. From temperature-dependent diffraction measurements the adsorption interaction is obtained for the different sites. In addition, inelastic neutron scattering (INS) is used to obtain insight into the potential energy surface that the adsorbed hydrogen molecules experience when adsorbed. This is done by analyzing the rotational transitions in the INS spectra of adsorbed hydrogen molecules. Such experiments are known to give detailed information on hydrogen adsorption sites in MOF’s and e.g. zeolites as well as on chemisorption of H2.

elements.content: The experimental characterization of the adsorption in MIL-53 is compared to first principles modeling. Modeling of the adsorption interaction in MOF’s has been performed by classical methods using force fields in several occasions and by using full ab initio methods at the MP2 level for certain fragments of a MOF. Ab initio calculations using density functional theory were performed in refs on the full primitive cell of MOF5 (also indicated as IRMOF-1), i.e., on a full periodic model. The adsorption energy values and molecular adsorption sites in the DFT results compare favorably with MP2 level calculations and experimental results in MOF5. For these reasons we apply DFT calculations here.

Materials and Methods

Materials Synthesis

The chromium MIL-53 was prepared using a similar method as described in ref . Fully deuterated materials were used in order to produce deuterated MIL-53 and to prevent the large incoherent background of protons in neutron diffraction. Samples were stored under a dry and inert atmosphere in order to prevent possible degradation. For the INS experiments protonated materials were used.

elements.content: Using an Ar glovebox, the neutron diffraction sample was put in a cylindrical aluminum sample container with a gold vacuum seal and connected to a gas handling system. Subsequently, the sample was degassed at 10−4 Pa and 150 °C to remove any remaining trace gases. When inside a helium cryostat the temperature was controlled to within 0.5 deg. Deuterium gas was loaded and unloaded at various stages during the experiments, and the amounts were monitored by reading the pressures and using a gauge volume at RT. Such volumetric methods determine the loaded amount of D2 independently. Each loading of deuterium was performed at 25 K in order to make sure that hydrogen was present in the gas phase when not adsorbed and also to ensure sufficient mobility of D2 inside the crystalline MIL-53 structure. Subsequently, the temperature was reduced to 10.0 K in order to perform the diffraction measurement with as far as possible reduced temperature factors for the D2. For the highest load the sample was saturated at 2.0 bar D2 and 25.0 K and also measured at 25.0 K (in order to prevent the condensation of liquid D2 in between the powder).

elements.content: In-situ neutron diffraction patterns were recorded during loading, unloading, and at various temperatures on GEM, a high-flux, and good resolution neutron diffractometer at the pulsed neutron spallation-source ISIS, Rutherford Appleton Laboratories, UK. Spectra typically required 10−15 min acquisition time. Rietveld refinements for data analysis were performed using GSAS. Aluminum diffraction peaks of the sample container are present below 2.45 Å, and they were omitted in the Rietveld refinements (most prominent peaks at ∼2.42, 2.01, 1.45, 1.2, and many below 1 Å). Typical R values (wRp) of the fit were ∼0.04−0.05 for each of the five diffractometer banks used. The deuterium molecule was fitted as a single D atom with a temperature factor of ∼0.17 (fitted independently at all temperatures and pressures), in agreement with the extended size of the molecule. Such approximation of the D2 nuclear density has also been used successfully in refs . The site occupancy by D2 thus equals half of the fitted D site occupancy.

elements.content: The rotational transitions of adsorbed hydrogen molecules can be observed using inelastic neutron spectroscopy. Experiments were performed on TOSCA, the neutron spectrometer at ISIS (UK) for energy transfers between ∼2 and 500 meV. In the region of interest here this instrument has a resolution of ∼2% ∼E/E, corresponding to ∼0.3 meV, facilitating the observation of individual excitations. Samples were handled in the same way as for neutron diffraction. The sample was loaded with para hydrogen, which was prepared in a separate cryostat using a magnetic catalyst and low-temperature H2. Again, the amount of H2 loaded was determined volumetrically.

elements.content: First principles model calculations were performed using density functional theory (DFT) in the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) as implemented in the VASP plane wave pseudopotential code. PAW-GGA pseudopotentials were used with an energy cutoff of 400 eV. For these large models a Monkhorst−Planck k-point mesh of 3 × 3 × 3 was used. Generally DFT codes have limitations in reproducing long-range dispersive interactions like the long-range tails of van der Waals interactions (see, e.g., ref for a discussion). Recently, however, it was shown that DFT with GGA pseudopotentials give good agreement of the adsorption energy with experimental results for hydrogen adsorbed in porous materials and for alkanes adsorbed in zeolites. When minimizing the structure, the space group symmetry of the model is maintained, while the lattice parameters and the coordinates of all atoms are allowed to change. The rotational barrier that has to be overcome when rotating a H2 molecule in the calculations as described in refs is compared to the para to ortho hydrogen rotational transitions observed in the INS. Such DFT methods to reveal the potential energy surface are also employed in for instance understanding the methyl group rotational tunneling in solids.

elements.content: A neutron diffraction spectrum of the empty sample at 10 K is shown in Figure (top) together with a spectrum of the maximally D2 loaded sample. After loading pronounced changes in the peak intensities are present indicative of the changes in the crystallographic unit cell content. The apparent average lower intensity of the Bragg peaks results effectively from a reduced nuclear density contrast in real space due to the filling of the pores with D2. Second, striking at first sight is the large increase of the background with D2 loading. This is a result from the incoherent scattering by the D nuclei, which is a direct measure of a large load of D2 in the sample. Third, a change in peak positions is present which indicates a significant change in the dimensions of the unit cell. The lower half of Figure shows the neutron diffraction spectra resulting from all measurements with increasing D2 loading and also of subsequent unloading of the sample: after the highest load at 25.0 K and 2.0 bar the temperature was increased stepwise, and deuterium gas progressively evolving from the sample was removed to keep the pressure at 2.0 bar. Measurements during unloading were taken from 25 K up to 150 K. From the figure it can be observed that the change in the dimensions of the unit cell is fully reversible; i.e., after the D2 is unloaded the crystal relaxes back to its initial dimensions.

elements.content: The diffraction pattern of the empty Cr MIL-53 sample can be refined with the I-mcm space group (no. 74) with lattice parameters of a = 16.772, b = 13.145, and c = 6.847 Å, cell volume 1509.544 Å3 at 10 K (parameters given in Table 1a of the ). There occurs only a slight decrease of the unit cell size because of cooling of the empty sample to 10 K and no other lattice changes; at 250 K a = 16.768, b = 13.126, and c = 6.845 Å, and the cell volume equals 1508.532 Å3. Although the diffraction patterns change strongly when D2 is loaded, they can still be indexed using the same space group for all temperatures and loadings. Using the space group information, Fourier maps are produced from the diffraction data which are shown in Figure . The framework molecular structure is reproduced in the Fourier maps (blue color). For increasing loading the position of the loaded D2 molecules is visible as the yellow shapes inside the MIL-53 framework. It is interesting to note that the site in the sharp corner near the Cr−O complex is occupied first (D1) and the site near the blunt corner second (D2). For increasing loadings also a site to the side of the benzene rings is occupied (D3). The central site in the pore is occupied last when the sample is saturated (D4). D2 on this site will have relatively weak adsorption interactions due to the fact that it is next to other D2 molecules, and clearly hydrogen−hydrogen interactions are only weak.

This indicates that no deuterium is missing in the refinements, nor that the amounts adsorbed are overestimated. The site occupations for the four different D2 sites during various stages of the gas release during heating from 25 to 140 K at a constant pressure of 2 bar are shown in Figure . At the moderate pressure used, 2 bar, there is still sizable D2 site occupancy at the D1 “sharp” site at 140 K, ∼20%.

elements.content: Several prominent features emerge from the results. First, the adsorption capacity when saturated at low temperature (below the freezing point of hydrogen) experimentally reaches 5.5 wt % while still not all sites are completely occupied. The fact that not all sites are fully occupied will be related to the limited space available within the pores and the van der Waals repulsion that will occur when hydrogen molecules start touching each other and the walls. In the modeling the sites were completely occupied for determining which sites were preferable, but also models in which the center sites were unoccupied were taken into account. This may indicate that in principle enough space is available to accommodate H2 on all sites simultaneously. We therefore might conclude that not filling all sites completely under the experimental conditions applied is a result from lack of space leading to the slow kinetics when most of the sites are occupied. Applying more pressure would have led to liquid/solid D2 between the crystallites.

For Langmuir isotherms the surface coverage θ is given by θ = KP/(1 + KP) where K is temperature dependent and varies according to K = (K 0/√T) exp[−E ads/k B T] with E ads the adsorption enthalpy and K 0 a constant. For the measurement at constant P this leads to the relation √T(θ/(1 − θ)) = P K 0 exp[−E ads/k B T]; i.e., in the plot of ln[√T(θ/(1 − θ))] vs 1000/T given in Figure the slope of the fitted lines should give adsorption energies E ads for the individual sites. elements.content: The INS spectra are plotted in Figure for several small loadings with para hydrogen. The signal of the sample loaded with hydrogen shows a clearly increased overall intensity compared to the empty MIL-53. The broad background is due to recoil of the hydrogen molecule. Several new peaks occur at low-energy transfers (<20 meV). The narrow peaks correspond to the rotational J = 0 to J = 1 transition of the para H2 molecule, J(1 ← 0). In principle, three lines are present (initial m = 0, final m = −1, 0, +1), of which the degeneracy is lifted depending on the geometry of the site in which hydrogen is adsorbed. For hydrogen in pure solid hydrogen the environment is isotropic, and a single, 3-fold degenerate, transition at 14.7 meV occurs. For adsorption on surfaces or in strongly hindered sites the degeneracy can be lifted, which thus gives information on the number of different sites and their geometry. The fitting of the spectra is performed using constraints on the intensities of the subspectra peaks as should be the case for rotational transitions (J, m) = (0, 0) to (J, m) = (1, 0), or J, m (1, 0 ← 0, 0) and (J,m) = (0, 0) to (J,m) = (1, ±1), or J,m (1, ±1 ← 0, 0) (peak intensities should have ratio 1:2). elements.content: The barriers for molecular rotation can be obtained using the standard anisotropic potential of the form V(θ) = V 0 cos2(θ), where V 0 is the potential energy barrier height. Such model assumes that there are only rotational degrees of freedom for the excitations studied in this energy range and assumes that possible (coupled) translational motions occur at higher energy transfers. This is a simplification of the physical reality; however, a full model that includes all degrees of freedom and possibly the interactions between the hydrogen molecules lies outside the present scope. For positive values of the parameter V 0 the molecule aligns parallel to a surface (2D case), and for negative values of V 0 the molecule is perpendicular to a surface (1D case). In the 2D case the degeneracy on the quantum number m = ±1 means that the lower energy peak will have twice the intensity of the higher energy component, whereas in the 1D case the opposite is true. Using the model described in ref , we can estimate a barrier height as well as an apparent rotational constant for the hindered hydrogen rotor expressed in units b H2, which is the rotational constant for unperturbed H2 (last two columns in Table ).

elements.content: The energy calculated for the barriers for rotation was obtained in the following way: a model was used in which all but the center sites were occupied by D2 because measurements were performed on the not completely saturated samples. Then a single molecule in the cell was rotated along different axes, and the minimum barrier for rotation was found from the energies calculated in the different configurations. The barriers calculated are somewhat larger than the experimental ones. A reason for that could be that in the simulation no translational degrees of freedom coupled to the rotations were taken into account, which could potentially lower the barriers for rotation as long as the molecule remains adsorbed. Another factor is that we do not use quantum wave functions for the adsorbed hydrogen. The more delocalized nature of a true wave function description would smear the atomic positions which in turn would tend to reduce the potentials, which would bring the experiment and modeling closer together. Nevertheless, the order of magnitude for the experimental barriers of rotation appears to be close to the currently modeled ones. Also, for all three sites the experimental and calculated barriers for rotation are smaller than the experimental adsorption energies, as should be the case.

elements.content: Figure displays detail images of the adsorption sites as found using diffraction and consistent with the minimum-energy positions from the modeling. The D1 site is positioned close to the Cr−O chain (Figure A) with the hydrogen directly above the O atom under it. However, the distance to the C−C bond of the acid group visible in the lower half of Figure A is much shorter than the distance to the O in the Cr−O chain (3.3 compared to 4.3 Å), and the H on the benzene ring at the opposite site is even closer (2.5 Å). In Figure an image of the calculated charge densities is shown, indicating indeed that the D1 molecular charge density interferes most with that on the C−C bond and on the H atoms close to the molecule. For this reason it appears that the D1 molecules do not adsorb particularly strong to the O−Cr chain, but rather that they adsorb to two sides of the pores: the C−C bond of one side of the pore and the two H atoms on the benzene rings on the opposite side. The D2 and D3 sites are shown in Figure B. The distances from the hydrogen atom nearest to the framework is smallest to the two different C’s of the C−COO groups nearby (2.6 Å), but the four O’s from these two COO groups are almost as close (2.8 Å). These O and C atoms therefore form a kind of cup that holds the H2. According to the modeling and the INS the barrier for rotation in this configuration is relatively low, indicating a relatively isotropic interaction with the environment. On the D3 site the distance of the adsorbed H2 is shortest to the H atoms on the benzene ring (2.7 Å), and the distance to the nearby oxygen atoms is 3.6 Å. Here too the charge densities of the D3 molecule interfere most with the H atoms on the benzene rings and not with the O atoms.

elements.content: In the present investigation the crystalline lattice appears to show substantial breathing deformation upon hydrogen adsorption at low temperature. Upon hydrogen release the structure relaxes back to the initial empty structure. In several metal−organic frameworks the adsorption of various solvents and alkanes has been shown to be responsible for such breathing, and also the uptake of CO2 has been reported to induce breathing of the crystal lattice. It is surprising that also for hydrogen, which is usually having only a weak van der Waals interaction and has no polar character, the breathing can be observed. At a small D2 content there is first a very slight breathing in the same direction as occurs for the uptake for a small amount of water. When MIL-53 in vacuum has the so-called MIL-54ht structure (space group 74) and it adsorbs water vapor, it transforms to the MIL-53lt structure with a decrease of the pore cross section and the unit cell volume and a lowering of the space group symmetry. In ref such a regime is found for hydrocarbons at low concentrations where the host−guest interaction dominates. Because hydrogen has relatively weak interactions with the host, the effect is much smaller. The largest breathing observed in Cr MIL-53 loaded by D2 is for higher loadings in the opposite direction from the large breathings that occur upon e.g. water uptake. It is interesting to note that the largest deformation occurs not at the lowest temperature with highest D2 load, but when raising the temperature and with a fraction of the D2 already released and under a pressure that has been built up (2 bar). This fact suggests that at these temperatures the mobility of the D2 molecules starts to build up, and the hydrogen molecules then require effectively more volume. This would be a different mechanism than for high hydrocarbon contents in the sense that there at high pressure the guest−guest interaction makes that more guest molecules are adsorbed at the expense of framework deformation. In diffusion measurements performed by Salles et al. it was indeed shown that rapid diffusion of hydrogen occurs in partly filled MIL-53 at temperatures of 77 K. On the basis of quasi-elastic neutron scattering results the typical residence time of a hydrogen molecule within a volume of 3 Å3 is about 5 ps, which indicates high mobility.

elements.content: Volumetric gas adsorption measurements were performed at a few different hydrogen loadings of the material between 0.1 wt % (low coverage) with the goal to determine the dependence of the observed average adsorption enthalpy on the surface coverage applied and also to determine the relation with the numbers found from the neutron diffraction. The results in Figure immediately make clear that there is a strong dependence of the measured pressures on the coverage. When fitting the pressure dependence with the expression P(T) = P 0√T exp(−E ads/k B T) the values E ads = 6.9, 4.7, 3.5, and 2.2 kJ/mol result at the coverages of 0.10, 0.20, 0.57, and 1.22 wt % H2, respectively. When comparing these values with the values obtained above from neutron diffraction, only the last two coverages have similar magnitude adsorption enthalpies. The value at the lower coverages compares favorably with what has been reported by Salles et al. also for low coverages. The dependence of the experimentally determined adsorption enthalpy on the experimental coverage used has been observed before in other MOF’s. The reason for apparent larger adsorption enthalpies at low coverage was indicated in ref as a result of the presence of low concentrations impurities that bind hydrogen stronger. The neutron diffraction performed here yields adsorption enthalpies at well-defined crystallographic sites and at coverages of up to 5%, i.e., not at impurity sites. We conclude that for Cr MIL-53 the gas adsorption at (too) low coverage does not give a representative adsorption enthalpy. In any case, from an application point of view, the enthalpy values at higher coverages are the most relevant ones: one needs to store significant amounts of hydrogen.

Conclusions

The uptake of hydrogen in Cr MIL-53 at low temperature results in the occupation of four different adsorption sites that can be resolved from both neutron diffraction and inelastic neutron scattering. Although the experimental conditions were such that full saturation of the sample could have been reached, this did not occur for all four sites. The adsorption sites near the Cr-O clusters reach the highest occupations. However, it appears that the interaction takes place mainly with the organic linkers that can touch the hydrogen from two sides when it is in these corner positions. There is a significant breathing of the structure, starting upon hydrogen loading, but especially pronounced when the temperature of the fully loaded sample is raised to above the boiling temperature of hydrogen. The breathing is in the direction of larger pore openings, which is opposite to what is observed upon e.g. water uptake. The temperature and pressure dependence suggests that the larger volume which is required by the hydrogen molecules as the temperature increases is responsible for the breathing. Modeling of the empty and filled structures can reproduce the adsorption sites found and can also reproduce the order of magnitude of the barriers in the rotational transitions of the hydrogen molecules.
